lessons.title: The Importance of the Training Program
lessons.lesson: This training for the youth is important because the “Great Lakes Youth Network for Dialogue and Peace. Our Diversity – our Opportunity'' project positions youths as a centerpiece for realization of lasting peace and sustainable development in their communities. Given this, the project recognizes the need for a strong network of peers and good contacts with other relevant actors, for the voice of the youth to create desired impact

lessons.title: The Organisation of the Successive Training Modules in the Handbook
lessons.lesson:
The handbook has eleven modules handling the different skills components youth from the different member organisations identified in the needs assessment identified as critical areas of capacity building in their conflict prevention and peace building initiatives. These include:

Introduction (Module One): Module one introduces participants to the training program and manual as a training tool. It aims to help participants understand the importance of the training program. Secondly, it aims to give participants the flow of the key successive modules of the training program. It includes for this purpose, a unit on the importance of the training program and another on the organization of the key successive trabing modules in the handbook.

Gender equality and equity (Module Two): Module two explores six content units. These include key concepts, stereotypes that perpetuate gender inequity and inequality, conducting a gender analysis using the different frameworks, conducting a participatory appraisal, developing gender aware plans and lastly, monitoring and evaluation of gender interventions. The objective is to build your capacity in gender analysis as an important part of the strategy for realisation of gender equity and equality in agencies and communities.

Critical Thinking (Module Three): Module three covers the skills in critical thinking one needs to avoid the common tendency of thinking simplistically about complicated issues and strive to appropriately consider the rights and needs of relevant stakeholders.  These include inferential skills, evaluative skills, problem solving skills, analytical skills, comprehension skills and cognition skills. The objective is to enhance your capacity to think smart when faced with a challenge that requires you to think critically.

Communication and Media Use (Module Four): Module four shares insights on how participants in peace building efforts can change how they consume media. Specifically, it will provide you with capacity building skills on the current media landscape, how you can navigate through different media, networking and also how you can fight media manipulation. Among other things, this module aims to help youth understand the media landscape, and how it is changing and to demonstrate how to use media to promote their work

Non-Violent Communication (Module Five): In module five, you will be covering the subject matter of non-violent communication (NVC)- the personal practice of not causing harm to one’s self and others under every condition when communicating. NVC is broad. You will however, focus on the NVC skills that stood out in the needs assessment particularly: usage of NVC/instrumental NVC skill, Knowledge of NVC Components/cognitive skill and usage of empathy skills. The module aims to impart participants from conflict prevention and peace building initiatives with key skills in NVC

Advocacy (Module Six): Module six is about the skills you need to successfully drive an advocacy agenda. The key units you will cover in this module involve: training in M&E skills for advocacy activities, advocacy project implementation skills, identification of available resources and timelines, identification skills for advocacy targets and lastly, definition of policy issues that need attention. The module aims to build the capacity of participants in advocacy as an important component of youth conflict prevention and management initiatives

Public Speaking and Debate (Module Seven) : Module seven focusses on public speaking and debate skills one needs to be impactful. In particular, the skills you will cover in this module include: the use of visual aids, use of the power of a pause, playing with the voice tone and control, practicing, managing audience relations and lastly, storytelling. This module aims at equipping participants with skills on the use of visual aids, use of the power of a pause, playing with the voice tone and control, practicing, managing audience relations and lastly, storytelling in public speaking and debate

Conflict and Conflict Management (Module Eight) : Module eightshares experiences on conflict management. It attempts to boost your understanding of the key terms of conflict and your confidence to engage in the peacebuilding process in your communities. Some conflicts are at an individual level. Others appear quite large-group level conflict. Depending on whether it is an individual or group level conflict, different skills are used in conflict management. The skills you will cover in this module are those participants in the needs assessment demanded most. At individual level, this includes mediation. At group level, the skills the module focuses on team building and cooperation skills, group building skills and advocacy for youth development. The module aims to build the capacity of participants with skills in conflict management both at the individual and group levels

Methods for Training Adults (Module Nine): Module nine offers skills and tools that will enble you to design and implement interactive learner centered trainings.  It will share facilitating experiences and you will learn facilitator tips, methods, as well as models of teaching including the variety of exercises related to re-energizing participants, and creative ways to make them want to participate actively and eventually practice what they have learnt in their lives or their work as peacebuilders. This module aims to equip participants will various skills as facilitators of trainings and how to plan and deliver an effective training

Organizational Development (Module Ten): Module ten covers networking skills, M&E skills, proposal writing skills, project delivery skills and impact visualisation skills. The aim is to equip participants with the knowledge in organizational development processes and skills in implementing key organizational development interventions.

Delivering an Effective and Safe Training in Emergencies like Covid-19 (Module Eleven): Module eleven provides basic information and tips on how to effectively organize trainings in the context of pandemics using COVID-19 as a case. The information and skills provided is generic for adaption based on your context to make your training a success. In particular the module wil take you through: The general knowledge about COVID-19, how to conduct trainings during COVID19, etiquette for conducting virtual meetings and lastly how to evaluate trainings using online platforms.

Conduct gender analyses using the different frameworks 
Conduct a participatory appraisal 
Developing gender aware plans

lessons.title: Unit Three: Key Concepts
lessons.lesson:
To understand the essence of the gender and the analysis it involves, it is important to master the associated key concepts. These include:

Concepts 1 & 2: Sex and Gender

Sex and gender are important concepts in gender analysis. Many people confuse and sometimes interchange these concepts even when they are different. To avoid these mix-ups, sex is defined as the biological and physiological characteristics that classify a person as either male or female. The characteristics of sex as a physiological variable are:

  • Universal
  • naturally unchanging; and

Gender on the other hand is defined as the collection of the socially and culturally constructed differences between males and females. The characteristics of gender include being:

Concepts 3 & 4:  Gender and Sex Roles

Like sex and gender, sex and gender roles are prone to confusion because of the confusion associated with the understanding sex and gender. Now that we understand what sex and gender mean, sex roles should be understood as the biologically determined functions distinct to females and males. Examples of sex roles for women include: Pregnancy, giving birth, breastfeeding.  On the other hand, the sex role for men is impregnation.  

Define gender roleson the other hand are the collection of behaviors, activities, tasks, and responsibilities that females or males learn in society (e.g., cooking, income generation, and decision making). Gender roles can :

Concepts 5 & 6: Gender Equality vs. Gender Equity

Another set of concepts popularly used in gender analysis that needs differentiation is that of gender equity and gender equality.

  • Gender equality as receiving the same resources regardless of sex. For example, all children have the right to free primary school, no matter if you’re a boy or a girl.
  • Gender equity as the fair sharing of resources, opportunities, and benefits according to the magnitude of need. For example, in primary school, boys need scholastics and uniform. To regularly attend school like boys however, girls have an extra need for pads. If not provided, they will miss classes and perform poorly.

Image: Illustration of gender equality and gender equity using soccer fans 

Concepts 7 & 8: Practical Needs vs. Strategic Needs

Gender analysis recognizes that women’s needs differ from men’s needs. When analysing needs of women and men, gender analysis makes distinction between practical gender needs/interests and strategic gender needs/interests

Practical needs are short-term needs that women themselves identify as essential in order to improve living conditions, but in themselves will not change the prevailing disadvantaged (subordinate) position of women. Women may identify safe water, food, health care, cash income, as immediate interests/needs that they must meet.

Strategic needs on the other hand are the long-term and aim to address the root of their subordinate gender position and ultimately change gender norms. They relate to issues of power and control, and to exploitation under the sexual division of labour. Strategic interests/needs may include legal rights, an end to domestic violence, equal wages and women’s control over their own bodies.

Concepts 9, 10 & 11 : The Women Triple Roles

  • Gender analysis recognizes that women’s needs differ from men’s needs because of the triple role women play, as well as their subordinate position to men in society. When analysing needs of women and men, gender analysis makes distinction in the triple roles women and men play in the society and household. These include productive work, reproductive work and community roles. Productive work/roles : This is work that produces goods and services for consumption by the household or for income and is performed by both men and women. Women’s productive work is often less visible and less valued than men’s productive work.
  • Reproductive work/roles : This work involves the bearing and rearing of children and all the tasks associated with domestic work and the maintenance of all household members.  These tasks include cooking, washing clothes, cleaning, collecting water and fuel, caring for the sick and elderly.  Women and girls are mainly responsible for this work which is usually unpaid.
  • Community work/roles : Women’s community roles include provisioning and maintenance of resources which are used by everyone, such as water, healthcare, education.  These activities are undertaken as an extension of their reproductive role and are normally unpaid and.  In contrast it is mainly men who are involved in politics at the community level.  This work may be paid or unpaid but can increase men’s status in the community

Concepts 12 &13 : Diversity & Inclusion

Diversity and inclusion are two interconnected concepts—but they are far from interchangeable. Diversity is about representation or the make-up of an entity. Inclusion is about how well the contributions, presence, and perspectives of different groups of people are valued and integrated into an environment (Matt Bush 2021). This means that an environment where many different genders, races, nationalities, and sexual orientations and identities are present but only the perspectives of certain groups are valued or carry any authority or influence, may be diverse, but it is not inclusive.

A diverse and inclusive workplace is one that makes everyone, regardless of who they are or what they do for the business, feel equally involved in and supported in all areas of the workplace.

Do you have diversity in your recruitment policy, in each of your departments, and in your leadership ? Or do you have a workplace where 50% of your employees are women but 0% of your women are managers ? Do you have good representation of employees of color overall, but all of them are in the same department ? These questions reveal true diversity and inclusion in the workplace.

lessons.title: Bienvenu!
lessons.lesson: Cette formation pour les jeunes est importante car le « Réseau des jeunes des Grands Lacs pour le dialogue et la paix. Le projet "Notre diversité - notre opportunité" positionne les jeunes comme une pièce maîtresse pour la réalisation d'une paix durable et d'un développement durable dans leurs communautés. Compte tenu de cela, le projet reconnaît la nécessité d'un réseau solide de pairs et de bons contacts avec d'autres acteurs concernés, pour que la voix des jeunes crée l'impact souhaité.

lessons.title: 1.5 L'organisation des modules de formation successifs dans le manuel
lessons.lesson:
Le manuel comporte onze modules traitant des différentes composantes des compétences des jeunes des différentes organisations membres identifiées dans l'évaluation des besoins identifiés comme des domaines critiques de renforcement des capacités dans leurs initiatives de prévention des conflits et de consolidation de la paix. Ceux-ci inclus:

Introduction (Module 1) : Le module 1 présente aux participants le programme de formation et le manuel en tant qu'outil de formation. Il vise à aider les participants à comprendre l'importance du programme de formation. Deuxièmement, il vise à donner aux participants le déroulement des principaux modules successifs du programme de formation. Il comprend à cet effet, une unité sur l'importance du programme de formation et une autre sur l'organisation des principaux modules successifs de traçage dans le manuel.

Égalité et équité entre les sexes (Module deux) : Le module deux explore six unités de contenu. Il s'agit notamment des concepts clés, des stéréotypes qui perpétuent l'inégalité et l'inégalité entre les sexes, de la réalisation d'une analyse de genre à l'aide des différents cadres, de la réalisation d'une évaluation participative, de l'élaboration de plans sensibles au genre et enfin, du suivi et de l'évaluation des interventions en matière de genre. L'objectif est de renforcer vos capacités en analyse de genre en tant qu'élément important de la stratégie de réalisation de l'équité et de l'égalité des sexes dans les agences et les communautés.

Pensée critique (module trois) : Le module trois couvre les compétences en pensée critique dont on a besoin pour éviter la tendance courante à penser de manière simpliste à des questions complexes et s'efforcer de tenir compte de manière appropriée des droits et des besoins des parties prenantes concernées. Celles-ci comprennent les compétences inférentielles, les compétences évaluatives, les compétences en résolution de problèmes, les compétences analytiques, les compétences en compréhension et les compétences cognitives. L'objectif est d'améliorer votre capacité à penser intelligemment face à un défi qui vous oblige à penser de manière critique.

Communication et utilisation des médias (module quatre) : Le module quatre partage des idées sur la façon dont les participants aux efforts de consolidation de la paix peuvent changer leur façon de consommer les médias. Plus précisément, il vous fournira des compétences de renforcement des capacités sur le paysage médiatique actuel, comment vous pouvez naviguer à travers différents médias, réseauter et aussi comment vous pouvez lutter contre la manipulation des médias. Entre autres choses, ce module vise à aider les jeunes à comprendre le paysage médiatique et son évolution et à montrer comment utiliser les médias pour promouvoir leur travail.

Communication non violente (module cinq) : Dans le module cinq, vous aborderez le sujet de la communication non violente (CNV) - la pratique personnelle de ne pas se faire du mal ni de faire du mal aux autres dans toutes les conditions de communication. La CNV est large. Cependant, vous vous concentrerez sur les compétences CNV qui se sont démarquées dans l'évaluation des besoins, en particulier : l'utilisation des compétences CNV/instrumentales, la connaissance des composants CNV/compétences cognitives et l'utilisation des compétences d'empathie. Le module vise à donner aux participants des initiatives de prévention des conflits et de consolidation de la paix des compétences clés en CNV

Plaidoyer (Module six) : Le module six traite des compétences dont vous avez besoin pour mener à bien un programme de plaidoyer. Les unités clés que vous couvrirez dans ce module impliquent : la formation aux compétences de S&E pour les activités de plaidoyer, les compétences de mise en œuvre des projets de plaidoyer, l'identification des ressources disponibles et des délais, les compétences d'identification des cibles de plaidoyer et enfin, la définition des questions politiques qui nécessitent une attention. Le module vise à renforcer les capacités des participants en matière de plaidoyer en tant que composante importante des initiatives de prévention et de gestion des conflits chez les jeunes.

This module aims at equipping participants with skills on the use of visual aids, use of the power of a pause, playing with the voice tone and control, practicing, managing audience relations and lastly, storytelling in public speaking and debate

At group level, the skills the module focuses on team building and cooperation skills, group building skills and advocacy for youth development. The module aims to build the capacity of participants with skills in conflict management both at the individual and group levels

Methods for Training Adults (Module Nine): Module nine offers skills and tools that will enble you to design and implement interactive learner centered trainings.  It will share facilitating experiences and you will learn facilitator tips, methods, as well as models of teaching including the variety of exercises related to re-energizing participants, and creative ways to make them want to participate actively and eventually practice what they have learnt in their lives or their work as peacebuilders. This module aims to equip participants will various skills as facilitators of trainings and how to plan and deliver an effective training

Organizational Development (Module Ten): Module ten covers networking skills, M&E skills, proposal writing skills, project delivery skills and impact visualisation skills. The aim is to equip participants with the knowledge in organizational development processes and skills in implementing key organizational development interventions.

Offrir une formation efficace et sûre dans des situations d'urgence comme le Covid-19 (module onze) : le module onze fournit des informations de base et des conseils sur la manière d'organiser efficacement des formations dans le contexte de pandémies en utilisant le COVID-19 comme cas. Les informations et compétences fournies sont génériques à adapter en fonction de votre contexte pour réussir votre formation. courses.title: Égalité et équité entre les sexes
courses.overview: Ce module a été préparé pour guider les ateliers de renforcement des capacités en matière d'égalité et d'équité entre les sexes. Le module comporte six unités de contenu. Celles-ci comprennent les concepts clés, les stéréotypes qui perpétuent l'inégalité et l'inégalité entre les sexes, la réalisation d'une analyse de genre à l'aide des différents cadres, la réalisation d'une évaluation participative , élaborant des plans sensibles au genre.
courses.objectives: Le module vise à renforcer la capacité des participants à l'analyse de genre en tant qu'élément important de la stratégie pour la réalisation de l'équité et de l'égalité entre les sexes dans les agences et les communautés.
courses.approach:
À la fin du module, les participants seront capables de : 
Appliquer les concepts et termes clés en matière d'égalité et d'équité entre les sexes 
Identifier et démystifier les principaux stéréotypes qui perpétuent l'inégalité et l'inégalité entre les sexes 
Effectuer des analyses de genre en utilisant les différents cadres 
Effectuer une analyse participative évaluation 
Élaboration de plans sensibles au genre

lessons.title: Unité 1 : Concepts clés
lessons.lesson:
Pour comprendre l'essence du genre et l'analyse qu'il implique, il est important de maîtriser les concepts clés associés. Ceux-ci inclus:

Concepts 1 et 2 : sexe et genre

Le sexe et le genre sont des concepts importants dans l'analyse de genre. Beaucoup de gens confondent et parfois échangent ces concepts même lorsqu'ils sont différents. Pour éviter ces confusions, le sexe est défini comme les caractéristiques biologiques et physiologiques qui classent une personne comme homme ou femme. Les caractéristiques du sexe en tant que variable physiologique sont :
• Il est universel
• Il est naturellement immuable ; et
• Il est biologique
Le genre, quant à lui, est défini comme l'ensemble des différences socialement et culturellement construites entre les hommes et les femmes. Les caractéristiques du genre incluent :
• Très variable d'une culture à l'autre
• Un comportement appris
• Continuellement sujet à changement.

Concepts 3 et 4 : Genre et rôles
sexuels Comme le sexe et le genre, le sexe et les rôles sexués sont sujets à confusion en raison de la confusion associée à la compréhension du sexe et du genre. Maintenant que nous comprenons ce que signifient sexe et genre, les rôles sexuels doivent être compris comme les fonctions biologiquement déterminées distinctes pour les femmes et les hommes. Exemples de rôles sexuels pour les femmes : grossesse, accouchement, allaitement. D'autre part, le rôle sexuel pour les hommes est l'imprégnation.
Définir les rôles de genre, d'autre part, sont l'ensemble des comportements, des activités, des tâches et des responsabilités que les femmes ou les hommes apprennent dans la société (par exemple, la cuisine, la génération de revenus et la prise de décision). Les rôles de genre peuvent :
• Changer avec le temps
• Sont affectés par l'âge, la race, le statut économique, la culture, l'éducation, la religion, la technologie, l'ethnicité, etc. ; et
• Changement basé sur des choix individuels, des changements sociaux ou politiques, des catastrophes naturelles et des conflits

Concepts 5 & 6: Gender Equality vs. Gender Equity
Another set of concepts popularly used in gender analysis that needs differentiation is that of gender equity and gender equality.
• Gender equality as receiving the same resources regardless of sex. For example, all children have the right to free primary school, no matter if you’re a boy or a girl.
• Gender equity as the fair sharing of resources, opportunities, and benefits according to the magnitude of need. For example, in primary school, boys need scholastics and uniform. To regularly attend school like boys however, girls have an extra need for pads. If not provided, they will miss classes and perform poorly.

Concepts 7 & 8: Practical Needs vs. Strategic Needs

Gender analysis recognizes that women’s needs differ from men’s needs. When analysing needs of women and men, gender analysis makes distinction between practical gender needs/interests and strategic gender needs/interests
Practical needs are short-term needs that women themselves identify as essential in order to improve living conditions, but in themselves will not change the prevailing disadvantaged (subordinate) position of women. Women may identify safe water, food, health care, cash income, as immediate interests/needs that they must meet.
Strategic needs on the other hand are the long-term and aim to address the root of their subordinate gender position and ultimately change gender norms. They relate to issues of power and control, and to exploitation under the sexual division of labour. Strategic interests/needs may include legal rights, an end to domestic violence, equal wages and women’s control over their own bodies.

Concepts 9, 10 & 11 : The Women Triple Roles

• Gender analysis recognizes that women’s needs differ from men’s needs because of the triple role women play, as well as their subordinate position to men in society. When analysing needs of women and men, gender analysis makes distinction in the triple roles women and men play in the society and household. These include productive work, reproductive work and community roles. Productive work/roles : This is work that produces goods and services for consumption by the household or for income and is performed by both men and women. Women’s productive work is often less visible and less valued than men’s productive work.
• Reproductive work/roles : This work involves the bearing and rearing of children and all the tasks associated with domestic work and the maintenance of all household members. These tasks include cooking, washing clothes, cleaning, collecting water and fuel, caring for the sick and elderly. Women and girls are mainly responsible for this work which is usually unpaid.
• Community work/roles : Women’s community roles include provisioning and maintenance of resources which are used by everyone, such as water, healthcare, education. These activities are undertaken as an extension of their reproductive role and are normally unpaid and. In contrast it is mainly men who are involved in politics at the community level. This work may be paid or unpaid but can increase men’s status in the community

Concepts 12 &13 : Diversity & Inclusion

Diversity and inclusion are two interconnected concepts—but they are far from interchangeable. Diversity is about representation or the make-up of an entity. Inclusion is about how well the contributions, presence, and perspectives of different groups of people are valued and integrated into an environment (Matt Bush 2021). This means that an environment where many different genders, races, nationalities, and sexual orientations and identities are present but only the perspectives of certain groups are valued or carry any authority or influence, may be diverse, but it is not inclusive.
A diverse and inclusive workplace is one that makes everyone, regardless of who they are or what they do for the business, feel equally involved in and supported in all areas of the workplace.
Avez-vous de la diversité dans votre politique de recrutement, dans chacun de vos départements, et dans votre leadership ? Ou avez-vous un lieu de travail où 50 % de vos employés sont des femmes mais 0 % de vos femmes sont des cadres ? Avez-vous une bonne représentation des employés de couleur dans l'ensemble, mais tous sont dans le même service ? Ces questions révèlent une véritable diversité et inclusion en milieu de travail.

courses.title: Esprit critique
courses.description: Ce module se concentre sur les compétences de pensée critique nécessaires pour éviter la tendance courante à penser de manière simpliste à des problèmes complexes et s'efforcer de prendre en compte de manière appropriée les droits et les besoins des parties prenantes concernées. Celles-ci comprennent les compétences inférentielles, les compétences évaluatives, les compétences en résolution de problèmes, les compétences analytiques, les compétences en compréhension et les compétences cognitives.
courses.overview: Huitt William (1998) defines critical thinking as the intellectually disciplined process of actively and skillfully conceptualizing, applying, analysing, synthesizing, and/or evaluating information gathered from, observation, experience, reflection, reasoning, or communication to guide the development of beliefs and taking of action. McPeck (as cited Garret, 2009: 8) in a simpler way however, defines critical thinking as the propensity and skill to engage in an activity with reflective skepticism.
courses.objectives: This module aims at equipping participants with knowledge and skills in critical thinking
courses.approach: By the end of this module, participants should be able to apply - inferential critical thinking skills-  evaluative critical thinking skills-  problem solving critical thinking skills- analytical critical thinking skills- And lastly, cognition critical thinking skills

Examples of sex roles for women include: Pregnancy, giving birth, breastfeeding.  On the other hand, the sex role for men is impregnation.  

Define gender roleson the other hand are the collection of behaviors, activities, tasks, and responsibilities that females or males learn in society (e.g., cooking, income generation, and decision making). Gender roles can :

Concepts 5 & 6: Gender Equality vs. Gender Equity

Another set of concepts popularly used in gender analysis that needs differentiation is that of gender equity and gender equality.

  • Gender equality as receiving the same resources regardless of sex. For example, all children have the right to free primary school, no matter if you’re a boy or a girl.
  • Gender equity as the fair sharing of resources, opportunities, and benefits according to the magnitude of need. For example, in primary school, boys need scholastics and uniform. To regularly attend school like boys however, girls have an extra need for pads. If not provided, they will miss classes and perform poorly.

Image: Illustration of gender equality and gender equity using soccer fans 

Concepts 7 & 8: Practical Needs vs. Strategic Needs

Gender analysis recognizes that women’s needs differ from men’s needs. When analysing needs of women and men, gender analysis makes distinction between practical gender needs/interests and strategic gender needs/interests

Practical needs are short-term needs that women themselves identify as essential in order to improve living conditions, but in themselves will not change the prevailing disadvantaged (subordinate) position of women. Women may identify safe water, food, health care, cash income, as immediate interests/needs that they must meet.

Strategic needs on the other hand are the long-term and aim to address the root of their subordinate gender position and ultimately change gender norms. They relate to issues of power and control, and to exploitation under the sexual division of labour. Strategic interests/needs may include legal rights, an end to domestic violence, equal wages and women’s control over their own bodies.

Concepts 9, 10 & 11 : The Women Triple Roles

  • Gender analysis recognizes that women’s needs differ from men’s needs because of the triple role women play, as well as their subordinate position to men in society. When analysing needs of women and men, gender analysis makes distinction in the triple roles women and men play in the society and household. These include productive work, reproductive work and community roles. Productive work/roles : This is work that produces goods and services for consumption by the household or for income and is performed by both men and women. Women’s productive work is often less visible and less valued than men’s productive work.
  • Reproductive work/roles : This work involves the bearing and rearing of children and all the tasks associated with domestic work and the maintenance of all household members.  These tasks include cooking, washing clothes, cleaning, collecting water and fuel, caring for the sick and elderly.  Women and girls are mainly responsible for this work which is usually unpaid.
  • Community work/roles : Women’s community roles include provisioning and maintenance of resources which are used by everyone, such as water, healthcare, education.  These activities are undertaken as an extension of their reproductive role and are normally unpaid and.  In contrast it is mainly men who are involved in politics at the community level.  This work may be paid or unpaid but can increase men’s status in the community

Concepts 12 &13 : Diversity & Inclusion

Diversity and inclusion are two interconnected concepts—but they are far from interchangeable. Diversity is about representation or the make-up of an entity. Inclusion is about how well the contributions, presence, and perspectives of different groups of people are valued and integrated into an environment (Matt Bush 2021). This means that an environment where many different genders, races, nationalities, and sexual orientations and identities are present but only the perspectives of certain groups are valued or carry any authority or influence, may be diverse, but it is not inclusive.

A diverse and inclusive workplace is one that makes everyone, regardless of who they are or what they do for the business, feel equally involved in and supported in all areas of the workplace.

Do you have diversity in your recruitment policy, in each of your departments, and in your leadership ? Or do you have a workplace where 50% of your employees are women but 0% of your women are managers ? Do you have good representation of employees of color overall, but all of them are in the same department ? These questions reveal true diversity and inclusion in the workplace.
